Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: US Ignite: FitGENI - The Impact of Video Fidelity on Fitness Efficacy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will assess the effectiveness of live fitness sessions broadcast via gigabit networking. Participation in regular group fitness programs and access to personal trainers is a way to improve the health of individuals, thus increasing lifespans and reducing the overall cost of healthcare. Significant challenges exist in the participation in regular fitness programs including cost, time and geography. There are over 251,000 registered fitness trainers in the USA which deliver group fitness and personal training programs at their local health clubs on a daily basis. This proposal seeks to explore the effectiveness of live broadcast fitness via gigabit networking and the impact of varying the video fidelity. The study will utilize the KinectHealth software application, GENI racks and the OpenFlow networking protocol. Kinect Health 3D was a Bronze price winner in the recent MozillaIgnite competition.

Obesity and its consequent diseases is a national problem that is a significant component of rising health-care expenditures. Exercise and even modest exercise-driven weight loss can significantly lower fasting blood sugar, improve glucose tolerance, and reduce blood triglyceride levels. This project will explore a network-mediated method of encouraging and facilitating regular exercise and will document its associated bandwidth requirements.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

POR.DRECONTENT:
Participation in regular group fitness programs and access to personal trainers is a way to improve the health of individuals, thus increasing lifespans and reducing the overall cost of healthcare. Significant challenges exist in the participation in regular fitness programs including cost, time and geography. There are over 251,000 registered fitness trainers in the USA which deliver group fitness and personal training programs at their local health clubs on a daily basis. If only there was a way to bring the expertise of the trainers to individuals in the convenience of their home or office through the use of mobile devices...


The goal of the FitGENI project was to explore the effectiveness of live fitness broadcasts from trainers to individuals using their own devices. Specifically, to what extent does the video stream resolution and frame rate impact the success of remote fitness sessions, as devices vary greatly in capabilities? Also, how is individual satisfaction with receiving fitness training through this channel, as opposed to going to the gym, impacted?


Definitively assessing the impact of video resolution of video training sessions on an individual's health requires an extensive longitudinal study over many years. This study is a first step in that direction. Instead of directly measuring fitness outcomes, the degree of difficulty individuals had in following the fitness instructor was used as a proxy under the theory that correctly following the workout should lead to improved fitness outcomes. Computer vision techniques were used to extract an individual's patterns of motion for comparison and a score from zero to one was derived to indicate how well a participant's motion matched that of the instructor.


Seventy individuals age eighteen and above who self-reported engaging in at least a moderate level of physical exercise participated in the experiment. Each participant performed three five-minute long workout sessions in a research studio. The workouts were mostly cardio with some lower-body strength exercises and a consistently moderate level of intensity. After each segment, participants were asked to fill out a survey rating the video workout they just performed on four subjective criteria: physical difficulty, visual quality, personal engagement and enjoyment.


The initial results of the study indicate that the there was no significant difference in the participant's ability to follow the instructor as the video resolution and frame rate varied. This is good news as it suggests that mobile fitness training is not only feasible but will also likely have the health benefits desired. While the effect of resolution and frame rate had little effect on the exercise routine, the results did indicate a substantial impact on user satisfaction. Participants reported greater engagement and enjoyed the workouts more when the video quality was higher.


In summary, mobile fitness content has the potential to improve the health individuals who are unlikely to utilize traditional training approaches. Preliminary results indicate that the effect of varied video resolution and frame rate, such as is the case with mobile and other personal devices, do not hinder the ability of individuals to participate in a training session. However, individuals expressed greater satisfaction and enjoyment with better video quality. Further investigation is needed to determine lasting effects but the preliminary results are encouraging.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 05/27/2015
Modified by: Mark K Gardner
